Co-based single-atom catalysts (Co-SACs) have attracted widespread attention in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). The coordination environment around Co active centers plays a crucial role in determining their intrinsic catalytic activity. This work systematically investigates the effect of introducing different numbers of S atoms into the Co-N4 coordination environment (Co-NxS4-x, x = 1––4) on the CO2RR performance at negative potentials. Among all structures, para-sulfur doped structure (p-CoN2S2) performs best with the limiting potentials for HCOOH generation of –0.19, 0, and 0 V at –0.23, –0.54, and –0.84 V, respectively. Compared to CoN4, the substitution of S atoms in p-CoN2S2 results in the emergence of two electron distribution peaks at –0.46 and –0.02 eV, primarily contributed by the Co d yz and d xz orbitals. This significantly reduces the band gap of p-CoN2S2 to 0.36 eV, much lower than that of CoN4 (1.82 eV), thereby enhancing the electrical conductivity. Additionally, p-CoN2S2 exhibits a higher occupation of the Co d z 2 orbital, which is beneficial for the electron transfer from Co atom to CO2, thus promoting CO2RR. This work highlights p-CoN2S2 as an efficient catalyst for HCOOH production, and demonstrates that the N, S coordination is an effective strategy to modulate the CO2RR performance at negative potentials. Graphical abstract This work demonstrates p-CoN2S2 as a promising single atom catalyst for HCOOH formation at negative potentials, and emphasizes that N and S coordination regulation can effectively improve the catalytic activity of SACs. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction Single atom catalyst Coordination environment Electronic structure Negative potentials Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) offers a promising approach to convert CO2 into valuable fuels and chemicals, helping to address the escalating concentration of atmospheric CO2 and the constrained reserves of fossil fuels [1–6]. However, the inert nature of CO2 renders it challenging to effectively transform into the desired products. Consequently, the development of highly active and selective CO2RR electrocatalysts has emerged as a critical solution. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) are a class of attractive CO2RR electrocatalysts, featuring atomically dispersed metal centers on support materials [7,8]. SACs have attracted significant attention due to their maximized atomic utilization, tunable active sites, and high catalytic activity. The Fe-NC catalyst has been demonstrated to exhibit a remarkable CO2RR activity, attaining a CO selectivity exceeding 80 % at a current density of 35 mA cm−2 [9]. Wang et al. reported that a simple method could be used to synthesize a mesoporous Ni-NC electrocatalyst, which could catalyze CO2 to CO with high a CO Faradaic efficiency (FECO) of 95.85 % and a CO current density (jCO) of −21.29 mA cm−2. In addition, the catalyst remained highly active over a wide potential range of −1.0 to −1.5 V (FECO > 93 %) relative to Reversible Hydrogen Electrode (RHE) [10]. Pérez-Rodríguez et al. synthesized Cu-N-C catalyst, which was active and highly CO-selective with low overpotentials (−0.6 to −0.8 V) at 0.1 M KHCO3, while H2 from competitive water reduction occurred with larger overpotentials (−0.9 V) [11]. The Co-N-C electrocatalyst obtained by Wang et al. exhibited a FECO of 99.4 % and a jCO of −24.8 mA cm–2 with a low overpotential of 0.49 V [12]. At negative potentials, the occupation of the Co 3d orbitals changed and led to an inversion of the Co-CO2 interaction force, thus facilitating CO2 activation. The d z 2 and d xz orbitals in the Co 3d orbitals played a key role in stabilizing the π* orbitals of CO2. Compared to other metal/NC single-atom catalysts, Co/NC exhibits superior CO2 adsorption ability and performance in the partial electron transfer (PET) step at negative potentials, which is more conducive to the formation of *COOH and the production of CO [13]. The unique coordination environment surrounding the isolated Co centers, such as Co-N coordination, plays a pivotal role in determining their intrinsic catalytic activity and selectivity [14,15]. Recent studies have shown that the introduction of heteroatoms, such as sulfur (S), into the coordination environments of SACs can optimize their electronic structures and catalytic performance [16]. Hou et al. observed that the N, S coordinated Ni-SACs induced a better catalytic activity in oxygen evolution reaction than single N coordinated Ni-SACs. They demonstrated that the introduction of S heteroatoms could reduce the electron donation from Ni to coordinated N atoms compared with that of Ni-N-C [17]. This suggests that N, S co-coordination may be a promising approach to optimize the performance of Co-based SACs in CO2RR, particularly under cathodic potentials. Motivated by these findings, we performed a comprehensive and systematic investigation on the coordination effect of Co-NC SACs on CO2RR performance under cathodic potentials. First, the structures of the Co-NxS4-x (x = 1–4) catalysts were optimized and their stability were evaluated. Next, the reaction pathways of CO2RR to HCOOH and CO were explored. Then, the limiting potential (U L) was employed as a descriptor to evaluate the CO2RR activity and product selectivity, as well as their competitiveness with hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Finally, we analyzed the mechanism through electronic structure calculations. We hope that this work would reveal the critical influence of N, S coordination on Co-based SACs in CO2RR, and provides valuable guidance for the rational design of high-performance CO2RR electrocatalysts. 2 Computational details 2.1 Simulation details All calculations were carried out by spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) as implemented in Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) 6.1.0 [18] with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [19] and generalized gradient approximation (GGA). The cutoff energy was set as 420 eV. To avoid the interaction of periodic units, the thickness of the vacuum layer was set to be 15 Å. The K-Points were set to be 3 × 3 × 1 for geometry optimization and 15 × 15 × 1 for accurate electronic density of state (DOS) calculations. The electronic energy and forces for structural optimization were converged to within 1.0 × 10–5 eV and 0.02 eV/Å. The electronic energy for frequency calculation was converged to within 1.0 × 10–7 eV. DFT energies were converted into free energies at 298.15 K by using vibrations obtained from VASP calculations with IBRION = 5. The van der Waals forces were described by applying the Grimme (DFT-D3) method [20]. The solvent influences were incorporated using the VASP implicit solvation model. The VASPsol model was employed to account for the effects of the electric field and counterions on the electrochemical double layer. VASPsol established a continuous charge distribution within the vacuum region of the simulation cell, which could assume either positive or negative values [21]. Consistent with recent literatures, the non-electrostatic parameter TAU was set as zero to preclude numerical instabilities [22]. The continuous charge was sampled at 0, 0.50, 1.00, and 1.50 e- to emulate different electric field intensities. 2.2 Computational hydrogen electrode model The computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [23] was employed to determine the changes of Gibbs free energy (ΔG), in which the reaction H+(aq) + e- = 1/2 H2 (g) was equilibrated at 0 V versus the RHE. Furthermore, the interfacial electric field effect on the reaction free energies was also considered [24], and Δ G ( U ) for each elementary step was defined as follows, (1) Δ G ( U ) = Δ E + Δ E ZPE + ∫ C p dT − T Δ S + Δ G U + Δ G pH + Δ G f i l e d where ΔE was the electronic energies directly obtained from DFT calculations, ΔE ZPE, ∫ C p dT , and ΔS were the zero-point energy, enthalpic temperature correction, and the entropy difference between the products and the reactants, respectively, which were calculated based on vibrational analysis and used to convert the electronic energies into free energies at room temperature (T = 298.15 K). Δ GU and Δ Gfield were the contributions from the applied electrode potential and the electric field to ΔG, respectively. The Δ G pH represents the pH contribution due to the variations in H concentration, and the contribution of pH was set as 0 for acidic medium in this work. The CHE model was also employed to determine the reaction free energies as a function of the potential, where the chemical potential of the proton-electron pair in the reactants was related to that of H2 at 0 V versus the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE), (2) μ H + + μ e − = 1 2 μ H 2 ( g ) . Chan et al. have evidenced that the surface charge density was an appropriate descriptor for the electrostatic effects of the electric double layer on reaction free energies [9,25]. Here, we related the surface charge density σ-dependent free energies to the potential-dependent free energies through the Helmholtz differential capacitance C H and the potential of zero charge ϕ PZC : (3) ϕ = 1 C σ + ϕ PZC where C H and ϕ PZC were taken as 21 μF/cm2 and −0.07 V vs SHE, respectively [9]. Consequently, the added continuous charges of 0, 0.50, 1.00, and 1.50 e- corresponded to the potentials of 0 V, −0.23 V, −0.54 V, and −0.84 V vs SHE, respectively. In the vibrational analysis of the intermediate states, all 3 N degrees of freedom of the adsorbates were treated as vibrations within the harmonic oscillator approximation, while the vibrations of the substrate surface were neglected. The potential-limiting step (PLS) referred to the reaction step with the largest Gibbs free energy change (ΔG max). The U L was defined by the equation U L = -ΔG max/|e|, where ΔG max was the free energy change in the PLS [15,26,27]. 2.3 Structural stability calculation The cohesive energies were defined as E coh = (nC E C + nN E N + nS E S + E Co - E base)/(nC + nN + nS + 1), where nC, nN, and nS denoted the numbers of C, N, and S atoms in SACs, respectively; E C, E N, E S, and E Co were the DFT energies of individual C, N, S, and Co atoms, respectively. The escape energy of Co atom was defined as E escape =E Co…SUB-E Co@SUB, where E Co…SUB was the energy at which Co atoms were near the surface, and E Co@SUB was the energy at which Co atoms were anchored on the substrate. The formation energies were calculated using the equation of E f = E Co@SUB - E SUB - E Co, where E Co@SUB, E Co, and E SUB were the energies of the SACs, the Co atom in bulk phase cell, and substrate, respectively. A more negative E f value indicated more favorable synthetic feasibility and thermodynamic stability. The dissolution potentials were calculated from the equation of U diss = U diss o ( metal , bulk ) − E f / e N e , where U diss o ( metal , bulk ) and Ne represented the standard dissolution potential of the bulk metal and the involved electron number in the dissolution, respectively. All the U diss o ( metal , bulk ) and Ne values were referenced from Guo's previous studies [28]. A more positive U diss value indicated that the metal atoms had stronger binding affinities with the substrate, which effectively prevented their dissolution and ensured great stability under electrochemical conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and stability In order to explore the N, S coordination effects on Co SACs, the Co-NxS4-x structures are designed. Fig. 1 shows the stable configurations of CoN4, CoN3S, para-sulfur structure (p-CoN2S2), ortho-sulfur structure (o-CoN2S2), and CoNS3. The lattice parameter of CoN4 structure is optimized to be 9.84 × 12.78 × 15.06 Å with all atoms in a plane. For CoN3S, one N atom in CoN4 is replaced by an S atom, resulting in a shortening of the Co‒N distance in CoN4 from 1.889 Å to 1.876 Å. Additionally, a new Co‒S bond is formed with the length of 2.125 Å. The CoN2S2 structure can be divided into two types based on the substitution position of the S atoms, including o-CoN2S2 and p-CoN2S2. For o-CoN2S2, the neighboring N atoms in CoN4 are substituted by two S atoms with the Co‒N length of 1.857 Å and the Co‒S length of 1.998 Å. For p-CoN2S2, two opposable N atoms in CoN4 are substituted by two S atoms, in which the Co‒N and Co‒S lengths are 1.916 and 2.117 Å, respectively. In CoNS3, the Co‒N and Co‒S bond lengths are 1.967 and 2.252 Å, respectively. As can be seen, CoN4 structure is distorted and form a non-coplanar framework after S doping. The non-coplanar framework and the changes of Co‒N and Co‒S bond lengths are primarily attributed to the larger atomic radius of the S atom relative to the N atom. To assess the stability of these catalysts, the cohesive energy (E coh), escape energy (E escape), formation energy (E f), and dissolution potential (U diss) are used as evaluation criteria. The values of E coh are 9.05, 8.91, 8.40, 8.39, and 8.50 eV/atom for CoN4, CoN3S, p-CoN2S2, o-CoN2S2, and CoNS3, respectively, as shown in Table S1 in the supporting information, demonstrating that these structures are all strongly bonded. The values of E escape are 4.91, 3.88, 2.98, 2.10, and 2.12 eV for CoN4, CoN3S, p-CoN2S2, o-CoN2S2, and CoNS3, respectively, as shown Table S1. The relatively large values indicate that it is difficult for Co atom to detach from the surface. The values of E f are calculated to be −6.14, −4.05, −2.30, −2.28, and −2.70 eV for CoN4, CoN3S, p-CoN2S2, o-CoN2S2, and CoNS3, as shown in Fig. 1f and Table S1. This indicates that all structures are thermodynamic stable and the order of synthetic feasibility is CoN4 > CoN3S > CoNS3 > o-CoN2S2 > p-CoN2S2. The values of U diss are 2.79, 1.74, 0.87, 0.86, and 1.07 V for CoN4, CoN3S, p-CoN2S2, o-CoN2S2, and CoNS3, respectively, as shown in Fig. 1f and Table S1. The positive U diss values indicate the excellent electrochemical stability of these structures for CO2RR. By analyzing the E f, E escape, E coh, and U diss, it can be concluded that these structures are all stable. It should be noted that CoN4 have been synthesized successfully and demonstrated excellent performance under electrochemical conditions [17]. Additionally, the metal-free N2S2 porphyrin with S atoms in the para positions has been synthesized successfully in the previous experiment [29]. Thus, all the studied Co-NxS4-x structures are feasible to be synthesized and would be stable for CO2RR applications. 3.2 CO2RR to HCOOH via two-electron pathway In the CO2RR process, HCOOH and CO can be obtained by the two-electron pathway. A plethora of experimental studies have confirmed that CoN4 and corresponding S-doping structures mainly produce CO and HCOOH, so we do not further explore the subsequent reaction of CO2RR. At neutral condition, the most competitive pathways to form HCOOH on Co-NxS4-x structures under different potentials are presented in Fig. 2 . The detailed free energy for each step is provided in Tables S3–6. As shown in Fig. 2, CO2RR to HCOOH tends to proceed along CO2 → *HCOO → *HCOOH → HCOOH. As shown in Fig. 2a, at 0 V, the PLS corresponds to the *CO2→*HCOO step on most sites except for the S site of CoNS3 where HCOOH desorption is the PLS with a ΔG of 0.62 eV. The ΔG of the *CO2→*HCOO step is relatively large on CoN4 (0.81 eV) and p-CoN2S2 (0.97 eV), indicating the formation of *HCOO is difficult. For other structures, an initial protonation energy of approximately 0.30 eV needs to be overcome for CO2 activation. As shown in Fig. 2b, at −0.23 V, the PLS remains the initial protonation step for CoN4 and p-CoN2S2 with ΔG lowered by 0.26 eV and 0.78 eV, respectively, compared to that at 0 V. For other catalysts, ΔG for the initial protonation are all negative and the PLS is the *HCOO → *HCOOH step. The ΔG of the PLS follows the sequence Co site of o-CoN2S2 > Co site of CoNS3 > Co site of CoN3S > S site of CoN3S > S site of CoNS3. At −0.23 V, ΔG of the PLS decreases for most catalysts except CoNS3 (Co site) and o-CoN2S2, indicating that the applied voltage is beneficial for the activation of CO2. As shown in Fig. 2c, at −0.54 V, the ΔG of the *CO2→*HCOO step is lowered by 0.37 eV compared to that at −0.23 V on CoN4, and the subsequent steps are also more favorable. On p-CoN2S2, both the PET step and HCOOH desorption are downhill. For CoN3S and o-CoN2S2, the ∆G of the *HCOO→*HCOOH step decreases compared to that at −0.23 V. On CoNS3, HCOOH desorption remains the PLS on both Co and S sites. Comparatively, p-CoN2S2 is more competitive for CO2RR to HCOOH compared to other catalysts at −0.54 V. As shown in Fig. 2d, at −0.84 V, the ΔG of the PLS for all catalysts is lowered. For CoN4, the PLS remains the initial protonation. On the Co sites of p-CoN2S2 and CoN3S, all the steps are downhill. As a whole, for the *CO2→*HCOO→*HCOOH, o-CoN2S2 (Co site) is identified as a relatively effective catalyst for CO2RR to HCOOH, requiring a reaction energy of only 0.17 eV at 0 V. Besides, p-CoN2S2 at −0.23 V, −0.54 V, and −0.84 V, as well as CoN3S (Co site) at −0.84 V, exhibit excellent catalytic performance. In addition, the generation of HCOOH via the *COOH pathway was also considered, as shown in Figure S8. At 0, −0.23, −0.54, and −0.84 V, the PLS for most structures is the initial protonation, with a higher ΔG than that of the *HCOO pathway. Therefore, the CO2 activation via the HCOO pathway is more favorable than the COOH pathway for generating HCOOH. 3.3 CO2RR to CO via two-electron pathway In CO production process, the reactions would proceed via CO2 → *COOH → *CO → CO, as shown in Fig. 3 . Figs. 3a-3d present the ΔG profiles for CO2RR to CO on different catalysts at various applied potentials. The detailed energy for each step is provided in Tables S3–6. As shown in Fig. 3a, at 0 V, the PLS is identified as the *CO2 → *COOH step with ΔG values exceeding 0.55 eV on the catalysts except for o-CoN2S2, where the *COOH → *CO step corresponds to the PLS with a ΔG of 0.67 eV. As shown in Fig. 3b, the PLS of the reactions for all catalyst at −0.23 V remains the same as that at 0 V. On the Co site of CoN4, CoN3S, p-CoN2S2, and CoNS3 and the S site of CoN3S, the ΔG for the initial protonation step is reduced by 0.26, 0.17, 0.46, and 0.32 eV, respectively, compared to those at 0 V. On o-CoN2S2, the ΔG of the first step becomes negative and the PLS remains unchanged with a slightly lower ΔG (0.51 eV). For the S site of CoNS3, ΔG of the PLS increases. Besides, except for CoN3S (Co site), the CO desorption is exothermic for the other catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3c, at −0.54 V, except for the Co sites of CoN4, CoN3S, and o-CoN2S2, the PLS is the initial PET step with reduced ΔG compared to those at −0.23 V. On CoN4, the first two steps exhibit consecutive downhill energy profiles, and the PLS is no longer the initial protonation but rather CO desorption with a ΔG of 0.11 eV. For p-CoN2S2, the overall reaction steps are relatively favorable with a ΔG of 0.03 eV for the PLS. As shown in Fig. 3d, at −0.84 V, for CoN4 and p-CoN2S2, the entire reaction steps exhibit a consecutive downhill trend. For the Co sites of CoN3S, o-CoN2S2, and CoNS3, the first two steps show a consecutive downhill trends, but CO desorption is highly unfavorable. For the S site of CoN3S, ΔG of the PLS is larger than that at −0.54 V. For the S site of CoNS3, the *CO2→*COOH step is identified as the PLS, and the subsequent steps of the reaction are relatively facile. As a whole, CoN4 is recognized as a good catalyst towards CO2RR to CO at 0, −0.23, −0.54, and −0.84 V. Relatively, p-CoN2S2 can achieve the CO2RR to both CO and HCOOH at −0.54 and −0.84 V, but is more inclined towards HCOOH production. 3.4 CO2RR performance CO2RR activity. The U L can be used as an indicator to evaluate the electrocatalytic performance of catalysts [30]. Fig. 4 a compares U L of CoN4, p-CoN2S2, CoN3S, o-CoN2S2, and CoNS3 in CO2RR to CO and HCOOH at −0.54 V vs. RHE. As can be seen, the U L values on CoN4 are −0.11 and −0.18 V, respectively, indicating that CO product is more favorable than HCOOH product. In contrast, HCOOH product is more favorable than CO product on p-CoN2S2. Notably, U L of p-CoN2S2 is more positive than those of the other catalysts and the reaction for HCOOH production can proceed spontaneously. For the Co sites of CoN3S, U L values are −0.24 and −0.07 V, respectively, yielding HCOOH product more favorable than CO. Conversely, CO product is more favorable than HCOOH product on the S sites. On o-CoN2S2 and CoNS3, U L for both CO and HCOOH is very negative, revealing their poor performance for CO2RR. Figures S4-S6 summarize U L values in CO2RR to CO and HCOOH on the catalysts at 0, −0.23, and −0.84 V. In comparison, at −0.54 V, p-CoN2S2 exhibits superior performance in CO2RR to CO and HCOOH, especially for HCOOH production. In summary, at negative potentials, the N, S coordination can effectively decrease the U L of CO2RR and enhance the electrocatalytic performance, rendering it a promising strategy for modulating SACs. CO2RR selectivity. As a side reaction of CO2RR, the possible HER must be taken into consideration as its thermodynamic equilibrium potentials is very close to that of CO2RR, which would lead to an intense competition with CO2RR. An ideal electrocatalyst for CO2RR should not only have a high conversion performance of CO2 but also excellent HER inhibition ability. The adsorption configurations and energies of CO2 are provided in Figure S7 and Table S2. As shown in Fig. 4b, at −0.54 V, the CO2 adsorption is more stable than H adsorption on all catalysts. Therefore, the adsorption of H is far less competitive than that of CO2 on these catalysts [31]. The Free energy diagram of HER and the U L difference between CO2RR and HER ( U L C O 2 RR − U L HER ) are shown in Figs. 4c-d. The positive U L C O 2 RR − U L HER denotes high selectivity for CO2RR over HER. In this regard, p-CoN2S2 demonstrates superior competition for CO2RR towards both CO and HCOOH products. Figures S4-S6 presents H adsorption, CO2 adsorption, HER free energies, and the U L difference between CO2RR and HER for the different structures at various applied potentials. Notably, p-CoN2S2 maintains favorable CO2RR selectivity at all negative potentials, underscoring its promising catalytic capabilities across a wide range of operating conditions. Comparison. Compared with previous calculations and experimental works at U = 0 V, the adsorption configurations, free energy change diagrams, and U L of CO2RR for CoN4 in this work are very similar to previous reported results [12]. This further confirms the accuracy of the calculated results. Moreover, U L values for CO2RR to HCOOH on p-CoN2S2 and reported SACs and Cu-based electrocatalysts are compared to highlight the superior performance of p-CoN2S2. DFT calculations predicted that FeN4 C had a U L of −0.69 V. Experiments found that Cu2O had a FEHCOOH of 97.7 % at −0.64 V [32]. The SnO2 nanoparticles exhibited a high total FE of 97 % towards electrochemical CO2RR at −0.95 V vs. RHE. The ratio of main products, CO and HCOO-, was intrinsically correlated with the variation in the surface SnOx/Sn ratio, and varied with applied potential [33]. Other electrocatalysts in previous studies presented U L values ranging from −1.14 to −0.74 V [34–36]. Comparatively, on p-CoN2S2 at −0.23, −0.54, and −0.84 V, U L for HCOOH generation are −0.19, 0, and 0 V, respectively, which are lower than those of most CO2RR electrocatalysts. Therefore, p-CoN2S2 would be an ideal electrocatalyst for HCOOH production. 3.5 Mechanism analysis To understand the N, S coordination effect in deep, the electronic structures of p-CoN2S2 and CoN4 are investigated by DOS and projected density of state (PDOS) in Fig. 5 . DOS and PDOS of other catalysts are provided in Figures S1-S3. As shown in Figs. 5a and 5c, after S substitution, p-CoN2S2 exhibits two additional distributions of Co-3d orbitals at −0.46 and −0.02 eV at 0 V. Fig. 5d shows that these two orbital distributions are primarily composed of the Co d yz and d xz orbitals, which effectively reduce the band gap from 1.82 eV of CoN4 to 0.36 eV of p-CoN2S2. Therefore, the substitution of the opposable S atoms has great potential to enhance the electrical conductivity and the intramolecular electron transfer, thereby promoting CO2RR. The d-band centers of the Co orbitals in p-CoN2S2 and CoN4 are investigated to evaluate the adsorption strength of intermediates. As shown in Figure S9, the d-band centers of the spin-up and spin-down d z 2 orbital are at −2.45 and −1.74 eV, respectively, for p-CoN2S2 and −3.31 and 1.50 eV, respectively, for CoN4. Comparatively, CoN4 possess a more portion of the d z 2 orbital above the Fermi level, implying that more antibonding orbitals are unoccupied by electrons, thereby enhancing the bonding with the adsorbed intermediates [37,38]. Besides, the average d-band centers (−0.91 eV) of the d z 2 orbital in CoN4 are closer to the Fermi level than that in p-CoN2S2 (−2.10 eV), indicating stronger adsorption of intermediate along the z-axis of the Co atom and subsequent hydrogenation. The d-band center analysis is consistent with the weaker adsorption strength of *COOH and *HCOO on p-CoN2S2 compared to CoN4 (Figs. 2 and 3). We also explored the DOS changes of CoNxS4-x SACs and intermediates adsorbed on p-CoN2S2 and CoN4 under different potentials. As shown in Figures S10 and S11, the main interaction between*HCOO and Co comes from O-p and Co d xz , d yz , and d x 2 − y 2 orbitals, and the main interaction between *COOH and Co comes from C-p and Co d z 2 , d xz , and d yz orbitals. As shown in Fig. 5b, for CoN4, as the negative potential increases, the down-spin d z 2 orbital moves below the Fermi level, and the d xz orbital approaches it. When the potential hits −0.54 V, the d z 2 orbital is fully electron-occupied. Given Co-C interactions mainly stem from d z 2 and d xz orbitals, and COOH primarily interacts with Co via its C atom (Figures S10 and S11), electrons from the d z 2 orbital above the Fermi level transfer to COOH, favoring further hydrogenation of *COOH on CoN4, which is not observed in p-CoN2S2 [13]. Moreover, at −0.54 V, the d yz , d z 2 , d xz , and d x 2 − y 2 orbitals all move closer to the Fermi level, indicating that a more negative potential can better activate these orbitals for adsorption, which is great for catalytic performance. As shown in Figs. 5b and 5d, as the potential becomes more negative, the d xy and d z 2 orbitals of Co in p-CoN2S2 are filled with electrons, which is different from CoN4. After adsorption of HCOO, electrons are transferred from the d xy orbital to HCOO, as shown Figures S10. In contrast, in CoN4, the d xy orbital is not filled, making it unfavorable for further hydrogenation. In summary, the N, S coordination environment can provide a favorable electronic structure for the Co-NxS4-x at negative potentials, which facilitates electron transfer to CO2 and reaction intermediates. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have conducted an in-depth theoretical investigation on N, S co-coordinated Co-NxS4-x towards potential-dependent CO2RR. The main points can be summarized as follows: (1) The N, S coordination provides a stable anchor site to form Co SACs, which demonstrate excellent thermodynamic stability and electrochemical stability with negative formation energy (−5.32∼−3.56 eV) and positive dissolution potential (1.50∼2.38 V). (2) In the two-electron CO2RR, CoN4 tends to produce CO, while the optimal product of p-CoN2S2 is HCOOH. (3) The best-performing p-CoN2S2 can effectively suppress HER and has high selectivity and activity. At 0, −0.23, −0.54, and −0.84 V, the U L values are −0.97, −0.23, 0, and 0 V, respectively. (4) After S doping, at negative potential p-CoN2S2 shows better conductivity and the electron contribution of d z 2 orbital and d xy is improved, which is conducive to electron transfer and Co-O bond formation, thus enhancing CO2RR performance. In conclusion, our study shows that p-CoN2S2 is a highly efficient catalyst for HCOOH production at negative potentials, and reveals that N and S co-coordination is an effective strategy for designing efficient SACs towards CO2RR. coredata.dc:description: Co-based single-atom catalysts (Co-SACs) have attracted widespread attention in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). The coordination environment around Co active centers plays a crucial role in determining their intrinsic catalytic activity. This work systematically investigates the effect of introducing different numbers of S atoms into the Co-N4 coordination environment (Co-NxS4-x, x = 1––4) on the CO2RR performance at negative potentials. Among all structures, para-sulfur doped structure (p-CoN2S2) performs best with the limiting potentials for HCOOH generation of –0.19, 0, and 0 V at –0.23, –0.54, and –0.84 V, respectively. Compared to CoN4, the substitution of S atoms in p-CoN2S2 results in the emergence of two electron distribution peaks at –0.46 and –0.02 eV, primarily contributed by the Co d yz and d xz orbitals. This significantly reduces the band gap of p-CoN2S2 to 0.36 eV, much lower than that of CoN4 (1.82 eV), thereby enhancing the electrical conductivity. Additionally, p-CoN2S2 exhibits a higher occupation of the Co d z 2 orbital, which is beneficial for the electron transfer from Co atom to CO2, thus promoting CO2RR. This work highlights p-CoN2S2 as an efficient catalyst for HCOOH production, and demonstrates that the N, S coordination is an effective strategy to modulate the CO2RR performance at negative potentials.
